root.pub-comments: “This subgrouping is based on both lexicostatistics evidence and on the evidence of unifiable innovation found among subsets of the languages” (Black 1974:8).
root.tree-val: Lowland East Cushitic, a subtree of Afroasiatic: Black 1974
root.publications: Black, Paul. 1974. Lowland East Cushitic: Subgrouping and Reconstruction.

child.pub-comments: “Galla is spoken by perhaps as many as seven million [people]...it serves as a lingua franca in many areas in Southern Ethiopia” (Black 1974:11).
child.geography: Western, central, and southern Ethiopia, and by additional speakers in northern Kenya.

child.pub-comments: “Somali is spoken by severanl million people...it has become the official language of the country [Somalia], and has come to be the only Cushitic language to possess an officially recognized orthography” (Black 1974:11).
child.geography: The whole of Somalia plus adjacent areas of French Somaliland, kenya, and the Ogaden region of Ethiopia.

child.pub-comments: “Rendille is spoken by a group of nomadic pastoralists” (Black 1974:14).
child.geography: Northern Kenya to the east of Lake Rudolf.
child.tree-val: Lowland East Cushitic, a subtree of Afroasiatic: Black 1974
child.publications: Black, Paul. 1974. Lowland East Cushitic: Subgrouping and Reconstruction.

child.pub-comments: “Bender (1971:218) estimates that the number of Baiso speakers as five hundred” (Black 1974:14).
child.geography: On Gidicho Island in the nortern part of Lake Abaya in southwestern Ethiopia.
child.tree-val: Lowland East Cushitic, a subtree of Afroasiatic: Black 1974
child.publications: Black, Paul. 1974. Lowland East Cushitic: Subgrouping and Reconstruction.

child.pub-comments: “It is spoken by some eighteen thousand speakers” (Black 1974:13).
child.geography: Around the northern end of Lake Rudolf, near the Intersection of the borders of Ethiopia, Kenya, and the Sudan.
child.tree-val: Lowland East Cushitic, a subtree of Afroasiatic: Black 1974
child.publications: Black, Paul. 1974. Lowland East Cushitic: Subgrouping and Reconstruction.

child.pub-comments: “Arbore is spoken by no more than one or two thousand speakers” (Black 1974:14).
child.geography: Along the northwestern shore of Lake Stephanie.
child.tree-val: Lowland East Cushitic, a subtree of Afroasiatic: Black 1974
child.publications: Black, Paul. 1974. Lowland East Cushitic: Subgrouping and Reconstruction.

child.pub-comments: “While the existence of the tribe has been known since first reported by Smith (1897:331), until recently it was believed that the Elmolo spoke only Samburu, a Milotic language. More recently the existence of a distinct Elmolo language has come to be recognized...which is perhaps now spoken by no more than eight of the Elmolo” (Black 1974:14).
child.geography: On the eastern shore of the southern part of Lake Rudolf and on an adjacent island.
child.tree-val: Lowland East Cushitic, a subtree of Afroasiatic: Black 1974
child.publications: Black, Paul. 1974. Lowland East Cushitic: Subgrouping and Reconstruction.

child.pub-comments: “Saho-Afar is spoken by perhaps as many as half a million speakers of two major dialects [Saho and Afar]” (Black 1974:9).
child.tree-val: Lowland East Cushitic, a subtree of Afroasiatic: Black 1974
child.publications: Black, Paul. 1974. Lowland East Cushitic: Subgrouping and Reconstruction.

child.pub-comments: "Although Saho and Afar have often been characterized as being distinct languages, Mahaffy states that they are connected by a chain of pairs of mutually intelligible dialects" (Black: 1974 9).
child.geography: Danakil Desert in northeastern Ethiopia and the northern half of French Somaliland, and to the north of this area in the vicinity of the Red Sea Port of Massawa.
